job_title: Medical Translator in San Jose, CA
pros: Santa Clara Valley Medical Center was an amazing place to work. Wonderful learning experience. Great pay, wonderful benefits. Great co-workers and my Manager, back in the day, Martin Lamarque was excellent. He lead by example, was fair and caring.
cons: There were a few coworkers that didn't work as they should and were conflictive but the Union protected them, which brought the morale of the others down.

review_title: Great way to step into a Hospital settings without a College Degree in Healthcare
job_title: Patient Transporter in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Available hours
- A lot of OT
- Substantial Raises from the County and Employer (Usually twice a year)
- Benefits
- Union has your back
- Laidback department
- Adequate management
- Great exposure to all departments within a Hospital
- Shift availability (morning, days, evenings)
- If you're curious about going into healthcare and didn't go to College or currently going to school, then this position would benefit you. Just don't get sucked up into the culture here. Some people in the Department have been working there for 10/20+ years and they have definitely created a toxic culture that rubs off on newcomers. I suggest getting in and advancing to another department after your first year.
- Really easy job: push, pull, and customer service.
- Yearly trainings
cons:
- No supervisors
- Our manager handled other departments within the hospital which takes the focus away from the employees. This made employees take things into their own hands.
- Being a County job, a lot of the people who have been within the company for a while acts like they own the place.
- Employees don't practice what's on the policy and make their own rules.
- Unprofessional the most times. 
- Everyone acts entitled and comes up with excuses about the job when it's listed in the policy. 
- Felt like being in high school again where everyone gossips about each other and can't talk things out like adults to resolve issues.

review_title: Hard to advance in your career
job_title: Extra Help- Clinical Nurse in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The nurses on my unit are a family. That’s the only pro side.
cons: County makes its very difficult for employees to advance in their careers. So many hoops to jump through. I was hired an as extra help clinical nurse I, trying to get county or management to pay you for your work is like pulling teeth. If you are due for a raise or annual review, they make you file paperwork and wait until management feels it’s necessary to submit it. RNPA is worthless, their only concern is helping the coded nurses but they still take the dues from EH nurses who already get paid the least. Found out that EH isn’t eligible for step increases so it’s nearly impossible to even get a pay raise until you go thru the process of filing more paperwork and hope your manager approves you for the title change. Stupid. Extra help nurses get dumped on with the least pay, no benefits and the promise of getting a code down the line. Nope, county won’t open more positions. Then they wonder why county if a revolving door of nurses, they can’t keep younger nurses who are the future of the hospital because they won’t pay them what they are owed.

job_title: Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very little. For an institution this size, it somehow manages to loosely provide patient care.
cons: Poor company culture, poor management, poor talent pool. Decades of unionized mentality, inadequate management skills, and very poor pay. If the county wants to be in the business of providing healthcare  in the bay area, it needs to pay like a bay area hospital to attract the right talent to turn this organization around.  Continuing to pay low only attracts the rejects of the industry and ultimately harms patient care.

job_title: Applications Coordinator in San Jose, CA
pros: Great benefits, although they're dwindling for new comers.  Great co-workers.
cons:
Culture is out of date with the current times.  Management still believes staff should punching a clock and watching every minute, yet they also expect you to be on call and be available for any emergencies, late night system upgrades, etc.  Double standard.

Management cannot be challenged or questioned, even if they are doing something wrong.  If so, you will be blacklisted and marginalized.  I've seen it done to numerous staff.

Those who are incompetent tend to be the ones who get promoted...they reward poor performers.

review_title: Very much a clique driven job environment

cons: In some departments, there is very much high schoolish clique work environment. Work assignments and promotions or job growth is based on who likes you not on your skill set, training or aptitude for a given job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Meeting and serving patients in government service (former healthcare professional). Great opportunity to work in the hospital and try a new role. Motivated, talented, passionate, and professional colleagues with big hearts joined me on the floor and I liked that. Paid health insurance. Many employee resources. Able to apply for transfers easily.
cons: Supervisor and Leads not knowing job role and patient population needs so they can't help. Gossip. Ineffective problem solving and making changes every day instead of rolling out a comprehensive list of departmental and task changes. Ridiculous micromanagement. Too many interruptions interfering with work processing. Employees ignoring supervisor requests to make changes and explain them to new hires. Being told different things by different people. Unwilling to deal with dysfunctional employee behavior. Two month delay in resolving tech problems making it very difficult to do job and other employees started having problems too. Centralize employees and documents to maintain department unity, address questions better, help others to all be on the same page, and keep documents all in one place. Inefficient, outdated processes and workflow and understaffing other employees hurrying to do work from beginning to end like many of the nurses.

job_title: Outpatient Psychiatrist in Gilroy, CA
pros:
-Very reasonable workload
-Great ancillary staff
-EXCELLENT amount of vacation/paid time off, probably the most in the industry
-Generous educational reimbursement
-Under normal circumstances no call obligations for outpatient docs
cons:
-Pay is low compared to cost of living in the area
-Periodic staffing crises forcing mandatory overtime at main hospital
-Patient population can be challenging to work with
-Social service resources limited; you do what you can with what you have
